questions.questionsTitle: Education is our right. Form groups and discuss our duties in this respect.

subQuestion.question: Education is our right. Form groups and discuss our duties in this respect.
subQuestion.ans: Rahul:Education is our fundamental right, but we also have certain responsibilities.

subAns.Column 2: I agree! Just having the right to education is not enough. We must respect our teachers and follow school discipline.
Absolutely! Also, we should help classmates who face difficulties in their studies. Knowledge grows when we share it.
One important duty is to spread awareness about education. If we see any child deprived of education, we must encourage their parents to send them to school.
Good point! Many children in rural areas still don't attend school. We can organize awareness campaigns to inform them about government schemes for free education.
Yes! And let's not forget to take care of school property like books, desks, and classrooms. It's our responsibility to maintain a good learning environment.
Well said, everyone! Education empowers us, but it comes with responsibilities. If each student follows these duties, our society will progress.

questions.questionsTitle: The State shall protect all monuments of historic interest and national importance. This is one of the Directive Principles. Find out the efforts made by the State about the conservation and protection of forts and make a chart.

subQuestion.question: The State shall protect all monuments of historic interest and national importance. This is one of the Directive Principles. Find out the efforts made by the State about the conservation and protection of forts and make a chart.
subQuestion.ans: The Indian government has undertaken several initiatives to conserve and protect forts of historical and national significance.

subAns.Column 2: Established in 1861, ASI is responsible for archaeological research and the protection of cultural heritage, maintaining over 3,650 monuments, including numerous forts.

subAns.Column 1: National Center for Safety of Heritage Structures (NCSHS)
subAns.Column 2: Led by IIT Madras, NCSHS focuses on the safety and preservation of heritage structures through research, training, and outreach activities.
States like Maharashtra have formed panels to safeguard ancient forts, with 47 centrally protected and 62 state-protected forts under their care.
ASI has developed CCMPs for forts like Salimgarh to ensure systematic preservation and management.
The Indian National Trust for Art and Cultural Heritage collaborates with government bodies for the restoration and management of heritage sites, including forts.
The Ministry of Culture implements policies focusing on the conservation and promotion of cultural heritage, addressing threats to historical monuments.

subQuestion.question: Find the odd man out.
subQuestion.ans: Unwritten sourcesReason:'Unwritten source' is not a source of history, while the remaining are sources of history.

subQuestion.question: Find the odd man out.
subQuestion.ans: StoriesReason:'Stories' are oral sources of history, while the remaining are material sources of history.

subQuestion.question: Find the odd man out.
subQuestion.ans: TemplesReason:'Temples' are a material source of history, while the remaining are written sources of history.

subQuestion.question: Find the odd man out.
subQuestion.ans: TarikhsReason:'Tarikhs' are written sources of history, while the remaining are oral sources of history.

subQuestion.question: Material sources.
subQuestion.ans:
Material sources comprise of different objects, different places, and their ruins.
These sources provide insights about the period to which they belonged.

subQuestion.question: Written sources
subQuestion.ans: Written sources of literature that help us to understand the history of different periods are called 'written sources of history'.

subQuestion.question: Oral sources
subQuestion.ans: Oral sources of history include various forms like owis, folk songs, tales, and legends that are passed down through generations by word of mouth.

questions.questionsTitle: Is it necessary to evaluate sources of history? Give your opinion.

subQuestion.question: Is it necessary to evaluate sources of history? Give your opinion.
subQuestion.ans:
Any source of information cannot be termed authentic just because it is old.
Sources of history have to be genuine and their quality & authenticity have to be determined as per the internal standards.

The Indian Constitution aims to create an atmosphere conducive to the development of the self as well as the entire society for which it guarantees equal rights to all citizens.
These rights are fundamental rights.

questions.questionsTitle: Plan how you will help a Varkari Dindi.

subQuestion.question: Plan how you will help a Varkari Dindi.
subQuestion.ans:
Food and Drinking Water Arrangements:Since Varkaris travel long distances on foot, they require a continuous supply of clean drinking water and nutritious food.
Setting up water tankers and filtered drinking water stations at various points will help them stay hydrated.For food, free meal centres (Annachhatras) can be established where chapati-vegetables, moong khichdi, snacks, and prasad can be distributed.
Local residents and volunteer organizations can assist in cooking and distributing food.
Appointing volunteers to maintain food quality and hygiene is crucial.

subQuestion.question: I know this :
subQuestion.ans: He was the eldest son of Umar Sheikh Mirza and had ascended the throne of Fergana in 1495 at the age of twelve.
Two years later, he conquered Samarkand but lost the city of Fergana soon after.
When he tried to conquer Fergana again, he lost control of Samarkand as well.In 1501, he tried to recapture both cities but could not succeed.
In 1504, he managed to conquer Kabul.
He formed a partnership with Safavid ruler Ismail I and reconquered parts of central Asia, including Samarkand.

questions.questionsTitle: Plan how you will help a Varkari Dindi.

subQuestion.question: Plan how you will help a Varkari Dindi.
subQuestion.ans:
Food and Drinking Water Arrangements:Since Varkaris travel long distances on foot, they require a continuous supply of clean drinking water and nutritious food.
Setting up water tankers and filtered drinking water stations at various points will help them stay hydrated.For food, free meal centres (Annachhatras) can be established where chapati-vegetables, moong khichdi, snacks, and prasad can be distributed.
Local residents and volunteer organizations can assist in cooking and distributing food.
Appointing volunteers to maintain food quality and hygiene is crucial.
